li.p: LF-movement of SE and Relativized Minimality

subsection.heading: 1 Introduction
subsection.p: The canonical Binding Theory of Chomsky (1981) is based on a two-way distinction between pronominals and anaphors. An anaphor must be A-bound and a pronominal must be A-free in its governing category. This two-way distinction is not exhaustive. As already observed in the 1970s (for instance, Ross 1970b; Kuno 1972b; Cantrall 1974; Hagège 1974; Clements 1975; Thráinsson 1976a, 1976b), certain elements that are formally identical to anaphors can be A-bound outside their governing category, or need not be linguistically bound at all. An important further observation was that, cross-linguistically, the two-way distinction between anaphors and pronominals found in English is the exception rather than the rule. In particular, many Germanic languages have a contrast between simplex anaphors, such as Icelandic sig, Norwegian seg, Dutch zich, etc., and complex anaphors of the general form <pron> SELF, where pron stands for a pronominal or simplex anaphor, which gives rise to three-way and four-way contrasts, not even counting anaphoric possessives. It took some time before systematic endeavors were undertaken to assess the theoretical implications of these observations.

The first attempt to systematically address the questions posed by the Germanic languages as a group is Everaert (1986b), who developed an approach to Binding based on chain theory, and explains cross-linguistic differences in Binding domains on the basis of independent structural differences between languages. Subsequently, Manzini and Wexler (1987) developed a theory of parameterization of Binding domains based on lexical differences between anaphors. Hellan (1988) proposed that Binding involves the interaction between two types of conditions: containment conditions that are purely structural (such as c-command) and connectedness conditions that require a particular substantive relation between the anaphor and its antecedent, such as predication command (the anaphor is contained in a constituent predicated of the antecedent) or perspective command, which requires that the antecedent qualify as a perspective holder. (As we will see, the latter type of condition is a typical indicator of logophoricity.)

One result of these works is that a distinction was discovered between local anaphors, which must be bound in their governing category, and long-distance anaphors, which are exempt from Condition A of the Binding Theory. 1 A second result is that the contrast between simplex and complex anaphors reflects properties of argument structure (as shown by Everaert 1986b; Hellan 1988).

The differences found by Thráinsson (1976a, 1976b), Maling (1984, 1986), Anderson (1986), Hellan (1991a), and Thráinsson (1991) between long-distance Binding into finite clauses (indicative or subjunctive) and long-distance Binding into infinitival clauses show that a further distinction exists. Only long-distance Binding into infinitival clauses reflects structural Binding. The other occurrences of long-distance anaphors are logophoric (as discussed by Clements 1975; Sells 1987). As such, their distribution is much freer, and they are governed by discourse, rather than by purely structural factors. (See chapters 9, 33, and 38 for discussion.) It will be important to further elucidate this distinction between structural Binding of anaphors and their interpretation by discourse processes in terms of a general theory of interpretive dependencies.
Below we will summarize some of the basic facts about the major Germanic languages, before once more addressing the nature of the pattern they present. 2

subsection.heading: 2.1 English
subsection.p: English has a two-way distinction between anaphors and pronominals. English anaphors (myself, yourself, himself, ourselves, yourselves, themselves) are SELF-anaphors. English anaphors are either locally bound or logophoric. Bouchard (1984) was the first to make a systematic contrast between anaphors obeying the canonical, structural, Binding principles and anaphors exempt from those, giving rise to dependencies that prima facie involve long-distance Binding. Pollard and Sag (1992, 1994) and Reinhart and Reuland (1991, 1993) state precise structural conditions under which SELF-anaphors are exempt from Condition A of the Binding theory. Their results indicate that many apparent cases of long-distance Binding can be analyzed as instances of logophoricity. It has been argued by Siemund (2003) and others (particularly Baker 1995) that other instances of exempt himself can be appropriately analyzed as representing a pronoun plus an intensifier (that is, himself = him + himself). Basically, this seems correct, although further research into the principles governing the distinction between logophoric and intensified instances of himself is still needed. A limited number of inherently reflexive predicates (mostly verbs of grooming, such as wash) allow the absence of an overt object where other languages require an overt anaphor (see chapter 9 for more discussion of English). This is a manifestation of the interplay between Binding and properties of argument structure, a phenomenon that is fairly residual in English but prominent in other Germanic languages.

subsection.heading: 2.2 Icelandic
subsection.p: Icelandic has a four-way distinction resulting from the fact that the SELF element sjalfan combines both with the third person SE-anaphor sig and with the elements in the pronominal paradigm (hann, etc.). In addition, Icelandic has a possessive third person anaphor sin. The anaphors sig and sjalfan sig must be bound by a subject, just like the possessive anaphor. When the antecedent is not a subject, hann sjalfan, etc., is used instead of sjalfan sig, and the corresponding pronominal form instead of sig or sin. In the first and second person the standard pronominal form is used throughout, with sjalfan where a complex anaphor is required. Sjalfan sig must be locally bound (i.e., bound within its governing category). Sig can be long-distance bound or interpreted logophorically. Icelandic freely allows violations of the Specified Subject Condition (SSC) (Chomsky 1973) with Binding into infinitives and DPs. Long-distance Binding of sig may cross a number of clausal boundaries, as illustrated in (1), where Jón is a possible binder for sér:

(1)
Jóni
sagði [Maríuj
hafa(inf.)
látið [mig þvo(inf.)
séri,j]].
John said Mary have made me wash SE
‘John said that Mary had made me wash him.’

Logophoric interpretation is possible only for an anaphor which is in the domain of a subjunctive, and which appears in a reportive context. For logophoric interpretation the antecedent need not c-command the anaphor. In fact, the antecedent need not be linguistically expressed at all. A systematic comparison between long-distance Binding and logophoric interpretation in Icelandic is given in chapter 33.

subsection.heading: 2.3 Faeroese
subsection.p: Faeroese, as it is described by Barnes (1986), has a three-way distinction. The SELF element sjálvan combines with the third person SE-anaphor seg, forming a complex anaphor seg sjálvan. In addition, Faeroese has a pronominal paradigm and a possessive anaphor sín. Combining a third person pronominal with sjálvan appears to give an emphatic pronominal rather than an anaphor. The distribution of simplex and complex anaphors in local Binding contexts is largely determined by properties of the predicate and appears to essentially follow the pattern found for Dutch. The complex anaphor is exclusively local. As Barnes (1986) notes, some speakers may allow a stressed variant of the simplex anaphor, and others colloquially even an unstressed one, where the majority requires a complex anaphor. Faeroese freely allows SSC violations with Binding into infinitival clauses and DPs as in (2): 3

(2)
a. Pæturi sá Mikkjalsaj bílæt av særi/j/sær sjálvumj/hunumo.
Peter saw Miichael's picture of SE/SE-SELF/him
b. Jógvani bað megj PROj raka særi/honumi/o.
Jógvan asked me to shave SE/him

The antecedent of an SE-anaphor must be the subject of a predicate containing the SE-anaphor. Thus, for instance, the indirect object of a subject-control verb is not a possible antecedent for an anaphor in its complement:

(3)
Egi lovaði Jógvanij PROi at raka honumj/*særj.
I promised Jógvan to shave him/SE
Faeroese also allows binding into finite complements subject to restrictions that are similar to the conditions on logophoricity in Icelandic (see chapter 33):

(4)
Jógvan segði, at Mortan hevði verið glaður, um Guðrun hevði kyst seg.
Jógvan said that Mortan would be happy if Guðrun had kissed SE

The majority of speakers allows both Mortan and Jógvan as antecedents for seg in (4). Objects, such as Jógvan in Eg fortaldi Jógvan . . . ‘I told Jógvan’ appear not to be possible antecedents. Barnes reports a relatively sharp Blocking Effect if intervening subjects do not have the same specification for person. So (5) is a variant of (4) in which the nearest subject is first person and the result is ill-formed:

(5)
*Jógvani segði, at tú hevði verið glaður, um eg hevði kyst segi.
Jógvan said that you would be happy if I had kissed SE

Such a contrast has not been reported for Icelandic. Given the impoverished verbal morphology of Faeroese (number contrasts but no person contrasts) as compared to Icelandic, this contrast is consistent with extant accounts of the Blocking Effect if number and person are checked separately. Note that the double intervention is not crucial; two-clause sentences with only the higher subject matching in features are also bad. However, if in (5) the nearest subject eg is replaced by Guðrun, and the mismatching subject is in a higher clause, the reading with seg dependent on Jógvan becomes considerably better. This fact merits further investigation.

Barnes mentions that this long-distance antecedency relation in Faeroese is almost exclusively found in the complements of verbs corresponding to English say, believe, want, learn (information), feel, intend. These are typically verbs of the sort licensing logophoricity in other languages, inducing a reportive context. As in Icelandic, the antecedent need not c-command the anaphor as in (6), or be linguistically expressed:

(6)
Vón hennarai var at særi fór at dáma tann nýggja prestin.
Hope her was that SE was going to like the new minister

What makes Faeroese particularly interesting is that, in contrast to Icelandic, it does not have an overt distinction between indicative and subjunctive. That subjunctive is not a necessary condition for licensing logophoricity is not new by itself. Many other languages (such as Chinese and Japanese, and also English) have logophoricity without a (relevant) subjunctive. The interesting question is what sets the Faeroese inflectional system apart from that of the mainland Scandinavian languages (and other Germanic languages) where logophoricity (at least involving seg-type anaphors) does not occur. Is it the particular feature composition of INFL or a particular distribution of the features over functional projections? Is it the fact that in subordinate clauses both Vfin Adv order and Adv Vfin order are allowed? (Or do these reduce to the same factor?) Is the subjunctive perhaps still covertly represented? To answer such questions, further investigation of the Faeroese facts is necessary.

subsection.heading: 2.4 Mainland Scandinavian
subsection.p: Mainland Scandinavian (Danish, Norwegian, Swedish), like Icelandic, has a four-way distinction (for discussion see, among others Hellan 1980, 1988; Vikner 1984, 1985a; Hestvik 1991, 1992). The SELF element selv combines both with the third person SE-anaphor seg and with the elements in the pronominal paradigm (ham, etc.). In addition, these languages have a possessive anaphor sin. The Norwegian anaphoric system may serve as a model for the system of mainland Scandinavian languages in general, since the systems are very similar. The main difference among the mainland Scandinavian languages is reported to be that Swedish själv differs from selv in not being obligatory in a case like Johan fraktade sig ‘John despised himself’ as it is in Norwegian (Hellan 1988: 97, fn. 10). The anaphors seg and sig selv must be bound by the subject of a predicate containing the anaphor. The same holds true of the possessive anaphor. When the antecedent is not a subject, ham selv, etc., is used instead of seg selv, and the corresponding pronominal form instead of seg or sin. As in Icelandic, in the first and second person the pronominal forms are used, with selv where a complex anaphor is required. Unlike Icelandic, Norwegian does not have a systematic use of seg as a logophor. This may well correlate with the absence of subjunctive in Norwegian (but see the discussion of Faeroese above). As in Icelandic, X-selv is local, and bare seg allows long-distance Binding. The following example illustrates long-distance Binding in Norwegian (from Hellan 1991a: 30):

(7)
Joni bad oss forsøke å få deg til å snakke pent om segi.
John asked us (to) try to get you to talk nicely about SE
‘John asked us to try to get you to talk nicely about him.’

For both possessive and non-possessive forms the upward bound on the Binding domain is the minimal tensed S (Hellan 1991a: 31), in accordance with Chomsky's (1973) Tensed -S Condition. This is illustrated by the ill-formedness of (8):

(8)
*Joni var ikke klar over at vi hadde snakket om segi.
John was not aware over that we had talked about SE
‘John was not aware that we had talked about him.’

One of the outstanding questions in the theory of Binding is what factors are involved in the limitations on long-distance Binding in languages such as Dutch and German as compared to Norwegian and other Scandinavian languages.

subsection.heading: 2.5 Dutch
subsection.p: Dutch distinguishes between pronominals (first and second person singular and plural, third person singular masculine, feminine and neuter, third person plural common gender), SE-anaphors and SELF-anaphors. The SE-anaphor zich only occurs in the third person (no singular/plural contrast). In environments where zich would be used for the third person, the first and second person are realized by a canonical pronominal form. Although, in general, complementarity between pronouns and anaphors holds, as in other languages, it should be noted that third person feminine singular haar, and to some extent also third person plural common gender hun, are not as bad as one might expect on the basis of Condition B. There is a SELF-anaphor zichzelf. In the first and second person the SELF-anaphor is realized as the corresponding pronominal plus zelf. Binding of these SELF-anaphors is strictly local.

Full pronominals combine with zelf as well in Dutch. Koster (1985) argues that the resulting element is an anaphor that is not subject to a local Binding requirement. The conditions on its interpretation show logophoric characteristics. Zich in positions corresponding to those of exempt anaphors in English is impossible in Dutch; zichzelf in such positions must have its antecedent in the local domain, as in (9):

(9)
Maxi telde vijf toeristen in de kamer behalve *zichi/zichzelfi/*hemi/hemzelfi.
‘Max counted five tourists in the room apart from himself.’
Logophoric interpretation of first and second person SELF-anaphors is available under similar conditions to those that apply in English.

Long-distance Binding of zich is possible, but it is more limited than long-distance Binding of Icelandic sig and Norwegian seg. Zich in te-infinitives (corresponding to to-infinitives) cannot be bound from the outside, as in (10), whereas zich in causative or perception verb complements can, as in (11) (see Everaert 1986b for extensive discussion):

(10)
Ik hoor dat Jani Piet gevraagd heeft een boek voor zich*i/hemi mee te brengen.
I hear that John Peter asked has a book for SE/him to bring
‘I hear that Johni has asked Peter to bring a book for SE/him*i.’

(11)
Jani hoorde Marie een lied voor zichi/hemi fluiten.
John heard Mary a song for SE/him whistle
‘John heard Mary whistle a song for SE/him.’

This latitude is restricted to zich in PPs. In the following cases with zich in direct object position, only local Binding is possible (in (12a) both readings are pragmatically OK; in (12b), where the local reading is pragmatically disfavored, the non-local reading is still impossible):

(12)
a. Jani voelde Mariej zich*i/j/zichzelf*i/j verdedigen.
John felt Mary SE/SE-SELF defend
‘John felt Mary defend SE/SE-SELF.’
b. Jani hoorde Mariej zich*i/??j/zichzelf*i/j verwensen.
John heard Mary SE/SE-SELF curse
‘John heard Mary curse SE/SE-SELF.’
With causative Exceptional Case Marking (ECM) constructions, judgments about object (relative to the lower verb) zich are essentially the same:

(13)
Jani liet Mariej zich*i/j/zichzelf*i/j wassen.
John let Mary SE/SE-SELF wash
‘John let Mary wash SE/SE-SELF.’
Indirect object zich, does, however, allow a non-local reading:

(14)
Jani liet Mariej zichi/??j/zichzelf*i/j een boek brengen.
John let Mary SE/SE-SELF a book bring
‘John let Mary bring SE/SE-SELF a book.’
Note that in some of these cases, replacing zich with a pronominal is less than entirely well-formed under the intended interpretation:

(15)
a. Jani voelde Mariej hem??i verdedigen.
John felt Mary him defend
‘John felt Mary defend him.’
b. Jani hoorde Mariej hem?i verwensen.
John heard Mary him curse
‘John heard Mary curse him.’
With causative ECM constructions, judgments about embedded object hem get sharper when the predicate is an intrinsic reflexive, as illustrated by the contrast between (16a) and (16b):

(16)
a. Jani liet Mariej hem*i wassen.
John let Mary him wash
‘John let Mary wash him.’
b. Jani liet Mariej hem?i verdedigen.
John let Mary him defend
‘John let Mary defend him.’
Embedded indirect object hem is fine, though:

(17)
Jani liet Mariej hemi een boek brengen.
John let Mary him a book bring
‘John let Mary bring him a book.’

subsection.heading: 2.6 German
subsection.p: German distinguishes between pronominals (first and second person singular and plural, third person singular masculine, feminine and neuter, third person plural common gender), and an anaphor, sich, which only occurs in the third person (no singular/plural contrast) and which superficially resembles an SE-anaphor. In the type of environments that require the anaphor for the third person, the first and second person are realized by a canonical pronominal form. There is an anaphoric form sich selbst which superficially resembles a SELF-anaphor. In the first and second person it is realized as the corresponding pronominal with selbst. Antecedents for these forms need not be strictly local. The theoretical implications of this are difficult to assess, given the fact that selbst occurs as a focalizing particle and focalization generally contributes to exemption (see Reinhart and Reuland 1993). 4 Also an interplay between Binding and argument structure is less easily observable in German. The form sich can be used in most positions where Dutch has zichzelf. Yet some contrast shows up in restrictions for sich to bear stress. For further discussion of sich versus sich selbst, see chapter 9.
Interestingly, in positions corresponding to those of exempt anaphors in English, sich selbst or ihn selbst are preferred, as in (18): 5

(18)
Maxi zählte fünf Turisten im Zimmer ausser *sichi/sich selbsti/*ihmi/ihm selbsti.
‘Max counted five tourists in the room apart from himself.’
Logophoric interpretation of sich and sich selbst with non-local antecedents is impossible in German. It is possible to have sich in a true expletive construction, though, as in (19):

(19)
Es hat sich ausgekuschelt.
It has SE out-schmoezed
‘Schmoezing is over now.’
Logophoric interpretation of first and second person selbst-forms is available under similar conditions to those for the corresponding SELF-anaphors in Dutch and English.

Long-distance Binding of sich is possible, but, as in Dutch, it is more limited than long-distance Binding of Icelandic sig and Norwegian seg. Sich in zu-infinitives (corresponding to to-infinitives) cannot be bound from the outside, as in (20) and (21), whereas, to a certain extent, sich in causative or perception verb complements can, as in (22):

(20)
Hansi befahl Peter [PRO ihni/*sichi/*sichi selbst jeden Tag zu rasieren].
John ordered Peter him/*SE/*SE SELF every day to shave
‘John ordered Peter to shave him every day.’

(21)
Ich hörte, dass Johanni Peter gebeten hat ein Buch für *sichi/ihni mitzunehmen.
I heard that John Peter asked has a book for SE to bring
‘I heard that Johni has asked Peter to bring a book for SE*i.’

(22)
Johanni hörte Maria ein Lied für sich%i/ihni pfeifen.
John heard Mary a song for SE/him whistle
‘John heard Mary whistle a song for SE/him.’

Apparently there is variation in the acceptance of the sich-variant in (22), indicated by the % sign before the subscript. Insofar as there is such latitude in ECM, it is limited to sich in PPs. In the following cases, with sich in direct object position, Binding is only local (in (23a) both readings are pragmatically OK; in (23b), where the local reading is pragmatically less plausible, the non-local reading is still impossible):

(23)
a. Johanni fühlte Mariaj sich*i/j/sich selbst*i/j verteidigen.
John felt Mary SE/SE-SELF defend
‘John felt Mary defend SE/SE-SELF.’
b. Johanni hörte Mariaj sich*i/j/sich selbst*i/j verwünschen.
John heard Mary SE/SE-SELF curse
‘John heard Mary curse SE/SE-SELF.’
With causative ECM constructions, judgments about object sich are essentially the same (note that a main clause reading of the pronoun is unobjectionable, unlike the case in Dutch):

(24)
Karli liess Paulj sich*i/j/ihni/*j/ihn selbsti/j rasieren.
Charles let Paul SE/him shave
‘Charles let Paul shave SE/him.’
Indirect object sich does not allow a non-local reading either: 6

(25)
Karli liess Paulj sich*i/j/ihmi/*j ein Buch besorgen.
Charles let Paul SE/him a book bring
‘Charles let Paul bring SE/him a book.’

Gunkel (2003) reports the following variation. Whereas adjunct PPs equally allow both the anaphor and the pronominal in ACI, as in (26), there is a difference between two types of complement PPs in (27) and (28): 7

(26)
Karli liess mich neben sichi/ihmi schlafen.
Charles let me next to SE/him sleep
‘Charles let me sleep next to SE/him.’

(27)
a. Karli liess uns nur ungern über ??sichi/ihni schimpfen.
Charles let us only unwillingly at SE/him scold
‘Charles let us scold him only unwillingly.’
b. Karli liess mich an ?sichi/ihni einen Brief schreiben.
Charles let me to SE/him a letter write
‘Charles let me write a letter to SE/him.’

(28)
Eri liess mich mit sichi/ihmi spielen.
He let me with SE/him play
‘He let me play with SE/him.’

From the perspective of our discussion of long-distance anaphora, it is important that German exhibits the same type of restrictions in this domain as Dutch and is quite unlike the Scandinavian languages.

subsection.heading: 2.7 Frisian and Yiddish
subsection.p: Frisian and Yiddish are to be mentioned only for sake of completeness in this connection. Since Frisian lacks an SE-anaphor and the forms used instead are truly pronominal, the question of long-distance Binding of SE-anaphors does not arise. Long-distance Binding of pronominals is, of course, possible throughout. One might still wish to understand, though, what is precisely the nature of the difference between himself, etc., in English, and himsels, etc., in Frisian. This issue still requires further investigation.

In exempt positions, the form pronominal-SELF has the same full range of logophoric possibilities as its counterpart in English and Dutch. For the purpose of the discussion of long-distance anaphors in Germanic it can, henceforth, be ignored.

Yiddish has a simplex anaphor zikh, which as in many Slavic languages is used for all persons, and a complex form zick aleyn, which in its use appears to be closer to German sich selbst than to Scandinavian seg selv. 8 A thorough analysis of Yiddish anaphora appears to be lacking. The literature (for instance, Weinreich 1971: 100–101) provides no indication that Yiddish has any long-distance or logophoric use of zick or zick aleyn.

subsection.heading: 3 Capturing the variation
subsection.p: As described in the previous section, there is considerable variation within Germanic in the domains in which SE-anaphors must be bound. As we saw, SE-anaphors may allow their antecedent in a position considerably beyond the governing category as computed in the canonical Binding Theory. The pattern has been taken to suggest that there are at least three possible (non-local) Binding domains across languages.

Systematic attempts to account for the variation observed include parameterized versions of the Binding Theory, with Binding-Theory-specific parameters, as proposed in Koster (1985) and Manzini and Wexler (1987), and a chain-based analysis in which the variation follows from chain formation interacting with independent structural differences, as proposed in Everaert (1986b). Manzini and Wexler, for instance, hypothesize that the governing category may vary across languages and anaphor types in terms of an opacity factor. The notion of an opacity factor generalizes the role of the subject in the canonical formulation of the Binding Theory:

(29)
a. b is a governing category for a iff b is the minimal category containing a, a governor of a and F (F an opacity factor).
b. Possible values of F include: (i) (accessible) SUBJECT, (ii) Agr, (iii) Tense, (iv) indicative Tense, (v) Root Tense.

Descriptively, this approach is quite successful. However, it leaves open by what principles the set of possible values of F can be restricted (otherwise predicting too many possible domains). Moreover, it treats Binding in all domains on a par, not distinguishing between logophoric dependencies and structural Binding.
Everaert (1986b) summarized the variation in the Binding of SE-anaphors we observed in terms of the following three domains:

Since the extension of the third domain involves logophoricity, variation in structural Binding domains appears to be limited to just domains (i) and (ii). Moreover, we saw that in Dutch and German the possibility of long-distance Binding does not extend to anaphors in the object position of the embedded verb. So the two relevant domains can be characterized as follows:

Everaert, followed by Reinhart and Reuland (1991), observes that the choice between (i) and (ii) is linked to an independent syntactic factor: (i) is found in the Germanic OV languages Dutch and German, (ii) in the Scandinavian VO languages.

There is a variety of proposals in the literature to capture the subject orientation and non-locality of SE-anaphors. Most of them explore the idea in Lebeaux (1983) and Chomsky (1986b) that restrictions on Binding correlate with restrictions on movement (cf. Pica 1985, 1987; Battistella 1987; Cole et al. 1990; Huang and Tang 1991; Hestvik 1991, 1992).

That SE-anaphors move can be argued to follow from the fact that they are underspecified for phi-features. Bouchard (1984) argued that in order to be interpreted, an argument requires a full specification of phi-features. From that perspective, being underspecified, SE-anaphors must acquire phi-features in the course of the derivation. This requirement can be met by association with an element carrying them.

One line, then, is to analyze the association of SE with a source for phi-features as an instance of X0- (head-) movement (assuming that SE is a head in, for instance, the D-position). The set of available sources is restricted: since heads can only move to head positions, the SE-anaphor can only receive the necessary features from another head. Verbs will not do (nor will prepositions, etc.), since they do not contain phi-features. A c-commanding NP will not do either, since it is a maximal projection. The only element that meets the requirements that it c-commands the anaphor, is in head position, and carries phi-features is AGR. 9 The result is summarized in (32):
(32) SE-heads associate with AGR at LF.

One may assume here that AGR is inside T (so the movement is to T), though nothing hinges on this detail. Since AGR is always co-indexed with the subject and SE-anaphors always associate with AGR, it follows that SE-anaphors, in their grammatical (non-logophoric) use, are subject-oriented.
This general approach raises a number of issues, both internal to the general theory in its form near the end of the 1980s, and with respect to subsequent developments.

subsection.heading: 3.1 LF-movement of SE and Relativized Minimality
subsection.p: Everaert (1986b) formulated a representational theory of anaphoric dependencies where proper Binding requires that the co-indexing between anaphor and antecedent creates a licit chain-type object. The anaphor must be properly governed by the index of its antecedent. This, in turn, requires a Barriers-style licensing of indices by a sequence of governing heads (see the discussion of NP-raising in Chomsky 1986b):
(33) DPi [Z . . . Zi [Y . . . Yi [X . . . Xi . . . SEi]]]

Lebeaux (1983) and, subsequently, Chomsky (1986a), in an endeavor to subsume Binding Theory under Movement Theory, developed an approach to Binding involving covert movement (LF-movement). Near the end of the 1980s it was found that movement obeys some form of Relativized Minimality condition (Rizzi 1990b). If SE-movement instantiates head-movement, it follows from any implementation of Relativized Minimality that subjects are not intervenors. In principle this could yield an extension of the Binding domain beyond the minimal governing category. However, the framework of Chomsky (1986a) puts severe limitations on head-to-head movement. The movement ‘passing through H’ sketched in (34a) is always illicit, since the intermediate trace violates the Empty Category Principle (ECP) (as discussed in, for instance, Baker 1988a). ‘Long’ head-movement skipping H as in (34b) is also ruled out: 10

(34)
a. [b ai b] . . . [H ti H] . . . ti
b. [b ai b] . . . H . . . ti

Roberts (1991b) argued that long movement is allowed if H is not a head of the same type, i.e., not an intervenor in the sense of Relativized Minimality. However, if (34b) is taken as the general model, it is predicted that SE always associates with the nearest source of phi-features, namely the local AGR. Since the actual binder may be higher up, one must either assume a dissociation between being a binder and being a source for phi-features, or assume that Binding is a by-product of attracting a larger constituent than just the anaphor. The former option underlies approaches modeled after Chinese (see Battistella 1987; Cole et al. 1990; Huang and Tang 1991; Huang and Liu 2001; see also chapter 9).

Another approach models the LF domain extension of anaphors on the overt formation of complex predicates in verb-raising languages like Dutch (Reinhart and Reuland 1991). This comes down to claiming that such anaphor movement uses massive covert pied-piping. SE first adjoins to its governing verb. 11 From there, V moves to I, taking SE along. The V/I complex thus formed may then move up further to a higher V, yielding a new complex, then to yet a higher I, etc., until SE with the V/I complex arrives at a position where SE associates with AGR. For an object control complement the structure is illustrated in (35). AGR is represented by the index on I; the SE-anaphor is, then, eventually bound by the subject of the matrix clause, as, e.g., in Norwegian (36) and (37):

First VsSE(2) is formed. Subsequently, VsSE(2) moves to I1, amalgamating in that position, then SE(2)/Vs/Ii moves up to Vm, and finally, SE(2)/Vs/Ii/Vm/ moves up to Ij. Here the SE-marked Verb is amalgamated with Ij, and SE may pick up the latter's phi-features. Interpretability only requires that SE gets its features at some point, not whether this happens when the verb merges with the lower Ii, with the higher Ij, or even with some higher-up I. Thus, in both (36) and (7) (repeated here as (37)) the anaphor will be able to be bound by the highest subject as required:

(36)
Jonj bad oss snakke om segj.
Johnj asked us to talk about SEj

(37)
Joni bad oss forsøke å få deg til å snakke pent om segi.
John asked us to try to get you to talk nicely about SE

Since finite clauses are opaque for ‘Verb raising’ and similar head-to-head movements, it follows that the upper bound for the Binding of an SE-anaphor is the first finite clause containing it (thus, this type of Binding observes the ‘Tensed-S Condition’). One may still wonder, though, what triggers such generalized verb raising. So far, this theoretical problem has no generally accepted solution.

subsection.heading: 3.2 The VO–OV contrast
subsection.p: An important question arising from this body of facts is how the contrast in Binding possibilities between Scandinavian VO and Dutch/German OV languages follows. As we saw, reporting an observation by Everaert (1986b), in Dutch and German zich/sich in to-infinitives cannot be bound from the outside, as illustrated in the Dutch example (38), whereas in causative or perception verb complements they can, as in (39). In Scandinavian languages, Binding is possible into both types of clauses:

(38)
Ik hoor dat Jani Piet gevraagd heeft een boek voor zich*i mee te brengen.
I hear that John Peter asked has a book for zich to bring
‘I hear that John has asked Peter to bring a book for him.’

(39)
Jani hoorde Marie een lied voor zichi/hemi fluiten.
John heard Mary a song for SE/him whistle
‘John heard Mary whistle a song for SE/him.’

Everaert (1986b) was the first to propose that this contrast follows from a difference in the configuration involving binder, matrix verb, and bindee, due to a difference in the position of attachment of the infinitival clause in OV/VO languages (using a framework in which the base position of the infinitival clase is to the left of the verb in OV languages, and to its right in VO languages). Reinhart and Reuland (1991) implemented this idea as follows. The embedded clause originates to the left of the verb, and is subsequently extraposed, leaving the trace indicated by tCP in (40) (using the then standard idea of rightward extraposition). If the extraposed te-clause moves to the right of the finite verb in Dutch (there is no possibility of attachment between V and I), the lowest available attachment site is that of adjunction to IP; thus the clause must end up higher than the finite verb, as indicated in (40a), omitting details. Zich and any verb within CPinfinitive it attaches to are not c-commanded by the higher V-I complex (e.g., heeft in (40)). Hence, they cannot form a chain headed by a higher I/AGR using the procedure illustrated in (35). This makes it impossible for zich to be interpreted. In Scandinavian, being VO, the complement clause stays in the VP (possibly after VP-adjunction) and is c-commanded by I, so the necessary chain can be formed. This is illustrated in (40b):

The general structure of this account is thus based on the idea that the OV structure creates a discontinuity in any chain-type dependency between anaphor and antecedent that is mediated by the governing verb of the constituent containing the anaphor. As such it is independent of the specific mechanism for chain formation assumed.

This particular implementation depends on the assumption that there is rightward movement/extraposition of te-infinitives. As is well known, this assumption is incompatible with most versions of current syntactic theory. 12

However, Everaert's insight that the OV structure creates a discontinuity prohibiting the establishment of the relevant dependency is not dependent on this particular implementation. In the next section it will be shown that it can also be implemented in theories without extraposition.

The other contrast between the OV and the VO languages concerns the impossibility of LD Binding of direct object zich/sich in Dutch and German (and indirect object sich in German) even in small clauses. This fact is also discussed in Everaert (1986b) (see also Reis 1976). Everaert notes that overt verb raising applies in Dutch and German, but not in the Scandinavian languages. On the basis of this fact Everaert proposes that the contrast can be reduced to a difference between full verbs and verb traces as licensers of anaphors. It will be interesting to investigate to what extent this view of the contrast can be maintained in current conceptions of clausal structure.

subsection.heading: 4 Conclusion: long-distance Binding and Minimalism
subsection.p: There is a tension between the requirement that arguments require a full specification of phi-features in order to be interpreted, and the fact that logophoric sig in Icelandic can be interpreted without an overt source for phi-features. This tension can be resolved by abandoning the requirement of full specification. This is discussed in chapters 33 and 38.

The general line that SE-anaphors move in order to acquire phi-features is also problematic from the perspective of the Minimalist program (Chomsky 1995c, 2000, 2001b), insofar as it is based on a self-serving movement of the anaphor that is not triggered by an independent requirement of feature checking. In this respect, a composite movement in which the anaphor associates with a verbal projection for Case checking, and the verbal projection moves further for independent reasons, holds more promise.

Any approach should do justice to the fact that these anaphoric dependencies are sensitive to variable properties of syntactic structure. That is, at least part of the computations involved is carried out within the computational system of human language in the Chomsky (1995c) sense (CHL). This requires implementing subsystems of Binding in terms of merge, move, and check. Also, any analysis should enable one to capture the role of the SOV/SVO contrast. For sake of concreteness, let's therefore assume that establishing a syntactic dependency with the antecedent is at least the preferred mode of interpretation of SE-anaphors (see Reuland 2001), and that this is accomplished by movement and chain composition (Chomsky and Lasnik 1993), leaving aside the precise specification of the triggers.

What most current approaches to the phrase structure of Germanic SOV languages have in common is that an ‘extraposed’ clause is in fact assumed to have been left behind in a low position by movements depleting the original verb phrase from verb and nominal arguments, where the latter material actually moves higher in the structure. There are two types of approach: one in which the VP gets depleted by a combination of head-movement and XP-movement, the other in which there is only XP-movement; cases where prima facie only V is moved are analyzed as involving moving a remnant VP (as for instance in Koopman and Szabolcsi 2000). For reasons of space it will not do to go into the details of the various extant analyses. It is important to note that there is a considerable class of analyses that all share the following structural pattern (for ease of exposition I am using traces and X′-notation with some unspecified labels in the representations; no theoretical status should be attributed to these notations).

In an SOV structure there is at least one step in which a phrase, properly containing the verb that originated as a sister to the complement clause, moves up to a position to the left of its inflection:

Suppose this position is combined with our earlier assumption that the verb must mediate in forming a chain-based relation between SE-anaphor and IAGR and subsequently the antecedent. For the sake of concreteness, one may assume that this is accomplished by post-cyclic chain composition along the lines discussed by Chomsky and Lasnik (1993) and subsequently Reuland (2001). It is easily seen that moving the verb (or a constituent containing it) from the sister position of the infinitival clause (indicated by ti), crossing IAGR, disrupts the possibility of forming a DP, IAGR, V, . . . SE chain. Assume that a dependency (checking relation, or agreement) holds between DP and IAGR. The next link in the dependency cannot be V, since it moved across. It cannot be tj either, since, being the tail of the V-constituent that crossed IAGR, it is inert. Hence, tj cannot participate in the formation of the dependency. Other options are equally unavailable, hence forming the dependency is blocked, and SE in the lower clause cannot be syntactically linked to the matrix DP.

In the Scandinavian SVO languages the verb stays to the right of inflection, hence lower than the latter. Since there is no crossing, nothing prohibits the matrix V from mediating in establishing a chain relation between SE and the matrix IAGR and subsequently the subject:

Precisely because in small clauses and bare infinitivals in Dutch and German, no ‘extraposition’ structures obtain, binding into these constructions is possible, except when some other process interferes. Further research is necessary to determine how Yiddish could fit in with this pattern.
Obviously, this sketch can be no more than a suggestion, since the details of timing and computation need more justification than can be provided here.

A precise analysis clearly depends on a very important issue, namely the identity of the precise mechanism involved in establishing a dependency between anaphor and antecedent. In principle, the process that previous analyses analyze as LF-movement of SE-anaphors can be implemented as feature movement in the sense of Chomsky (1995c), triggered by standard checking requirements involving EPP and Case (as, for instance, in Reuland 2001) followed by chain composition. Alternatively, the basis of the dependencies could be found in the AGREE relation (Chomsky 2001b). Hornstein (2001) and Kayne (2002) develop analyses in which at least some Binding relations are directly encoded by movement. Discussing these implementations would carry us beyond the scope of this chapter, and will have to wait for another occasion.

subsection.p: I would like to thank Patrick Brandt, Martin Everaert, and two anonymous reviewers for their very helpful comments. The usual disclaimers apply.

li.p: Ich möchte nicht dass Hans für jemand anderen arbeitet. Ich möchte dass er für mich selbst arbeitet.
‘I do not want John to work for somebody else. I want him to work for myself.’
Hans will nicht, dass ich für jemand anders arbeite. Deshalb lässt er mich nur für sich selbst arbeiten.
‘John does not want me to work for somebody else. Therefore he lets me work only for himself.’

subsection.p: Note that in these cases the selbst-form is heavily focused. The precise role of structure vs. focus still merits further investigation. As the reviewer points out, selbst combines with third person pronouns as well, but there is no reason to treat such forms as anaphors (or logophors).

Patrick Brandt (p.c.) reports that if nur ungern is omitted from (27a) the contrast gets much sharper, as in (i), and similarly if one has the DP–PP order as in (ii):

Karli liess mich ein Päckchen zu ??sichi/zu ihmi schicken.
Charles let me a package to SE/him send
‘Charles let me send a package to him.’

subsection.p: Further research will no doubt shed more light on these contrasts.

9 With Borer (1989), one may assume that both infinitival and finite INFL are associated with AGR, which is anaphoric in the former case. Anaphoric AGR bears phi-features just like finite AGR; hence it is equally suitable as a ‘host’ supplying these features to the SE-anaphor. In order to allow subjects of small clauses as antecedents of SE-anaphors, we have to assume that small clauses carry AGR too. Much of the current literature makes this assumption, although direct empirical arguments like those for anaphoric AGR in infinitival clauses are lacking.

10 Note that we are assuming that SE-movement is an instantiation of canonical head-movement. Although it may be tempting to equate SE-movement with clitic movement of some sort, clitic movement seems to be freer (see Kayne 1990 for discussion), and may well be a different phenomenon. (It certainly involves different conditions; also witness the fact that languages may have SE-anaphors without having true clitics.)

11 This has no effect on the verb's interpretation, since SE is neither a reflexivizer nor a clitic which satisfies a grid position lexically; it just leaves the relevant thematic position unsaturated, until it receives phi-features.

12 As noted by an anonymous reviewer, another problem appears to be posed by the fact that at least German CP-infinitives (zu-infinitives) need not be extraposed. Yet in these structures also long-distance Binding from outside the zu-infinitive is prohibited, as illustrated in (i):

subsection.p: (i) dass Hansi unsj [CP PROj ihmi/*sichi ein Buch mitzubringen] bat
Pursuing this issue would lead us beyond the scope of this chapter, however.
